Award.AwardTitle: Non-linear partial differential equations in geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the principal investigators will study several higher-order nonlinear partial differential equations that arise in conformal geometry and Cauchy-Riemann (CR) geometry. These equations describe the effect on the curvatures of the new structures of making conformal changes of metrics (as in conformal geometry) or of contact forms (as in CR-geometry). Of particular interest are equations that prescribe higher-order curvature invariants that control the global geometry of higher dimensional manifolds. The project seeks to develop new tools to solve these equations and to describe the behavior of the solutions. A key difficulty in handling such equations is the absence of a maximum principle, and the principal investigators propose to compensate for its absence by using integral inequalities as the main working tool. It is expected that the study will yield extensions of the well-known mixed volume inequalities to more general domains in Euclidean space, as well as sharp Sobolev inequalities in CR-geometry.

The goal of this project is to provide new insights into and to create new tools for the study of the theory of geometric partial differential equations, a subject that has evolved into a basic toolbox in many areas in mathematics, applied mathematics, and engineering, to say nothing of mathematical physics. One of the main topics of study in the project (namely, the existence of so-called Einstein space) is motivated by a conjecture that physicists call the "holography principle." It asserts that the results of any measurements of the physical universe in the Einstein space can be predicted by taking another set of measurements near the "far end" of the universe (which is referred to as its "boundary"). A case of particular interest is the situation when the boundary space is three-dimensional, a case in which geometric understanding is already well developed. The project will engage graduate students and postdocs in its research activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During this grant period the PIs Alice Chang and Paul Yang studied the
PDE approach for analytic questions in conformal and CR geometry. They
continue to find new equations which arise naturally in these geometries
and study the nature and existence of their solutions. They also spend a
good portion of their energy in the training of young students and
postdocs in the research in these directions.

In the joint work of Chang and Y. Wang they employ the modern theory of
optimal transport to the isoperimetric problem for domains with smooth
boundaries. The classical isoperimetric inequality asserts an inequality
comparing the area of a plane region to the length squared of its
boundary, and says that the inequality becomes an equality exactly when
the region is a circle. This is at the basis of a family of geometric
inequalities relating certain measurements of a general domain to
certain other measurements of its boundary. These inequality are crucial
in understanding how the boundary geometry constrains the interior
geometry. In this series of work they extend the previously known inequality (usually assuming the domains satisfy some convexity assumptions) to more general situations of significant interest in geometry.

A lot of recent progress in conformal geometry was driven in part by the
discovery of several conformally invariant differential equations of
higher order. The order means the number of times differentiation takes
place in the leading term of the equation. The right hand side of these
equations contains certain new curvature quantities which are called
Q-curvature and their integral often give rise to new global geometric
invariants. In the work of Chang and Gonzalez, the center of focus is the newly developed fractional order equation for which they found estimates for the equation. This work is in the setting of general manifolds, thus making accessible the study of this equation for researchers with geometric backgrounds. Similarly, Chang and J. Case extended these equations to arbitrary order on manifolds with boundary. They derived the relevant Sobolev inequalities which are fundamental for future progress in working on these equations. Chang had lectured extensively on this recent development to young researhers in many countries.

The PIs had been among the pioneers to develop what is
called conformally covariant operators of general order, here the order
means the number of times the quantity is being differentiated. Such
operators always define an associated curvature quantity whose integral
replaces the previously mentioned area and volume.

Yang and F. Hang study the 4th-order operators in conformal geometry in
general dimensions. A stumbling block to the development of the theory
has been the lack of strong maximum principal which is traditionally used to
show the suitable solutions of such equations are alway positive. In a
series of paper devoted to study the signs of Green's function (the
solution operator). They provide useful critera for positivity, thus making this
equation accessble to the analysts. In addition, their study of the Green's
function also yields the positivity of a quantity called the mass of this
operator and is fundamental for the solvability of this equations. This
positive development opens up the study of these operators to the
geometers. They have given extensive lectures about these results through out the US, Singapore and China.

In a new direction, Yang and a group of collaborators including A. Malchiodi in Pisa, J. Cheng J. Hwang and H. Chiu in Taiwan, and S. Chanillo
in Rutgers and J. Case in Penn State had developed a natural fourth order operator in CR geometrywhich plays an important role in the realization problem for three dimensional CR structures as well as the solvability of several important basic linear equations for these CR structures. A host of new result such as the positivity of the CR mass are derived through the understanding of this new operator. In addition, J. Case and Yang have formulated a secondary operator to this 4th order operator and it gives rise to a new invariant which plays the decisive role in a global version of the Gauss
Bonnet formula which relates the geometry to the underlying topology of the
space. This has opened the way to a possible classification of three
dimensional CR structures based on this new invariant.
